message: Can anyone recommend a good place to look for devs to do small pieces of work - many of which are probably only 5 or 6 hours each?  An online site like RentaCoder or another?  Is $25-35/hr reasonable?

oDesk.com is currently trying to get an ad link on the python.org web site (which they won't, because they don't have specific jobs). So you may get Python coders there. The rate seems quite low for an experienced sys admin professional, so you should expect the number of hours taken for a task to be somewhat larger than you might anticipate.
I've used oDesk in the past to employ admins, including the PSF admin until she became full time. Sorry, not sure why I thought your question was related to system administration.
@alexh feel free to contact me, I'm always looking for small projects to keep me busy.
@alexh our rate is $30, we do django for more than 3 years, feel free to contact me
/hour
Sounds like this is a pretty good place to post =) - I know a few Django devs  who take on small side projects.
but you have to sell yourself to the developer as trustworthy in that case ;)
I think in my case, I'd tackle risk by starting with tasks an hour or two long.  That limits the risk to both sides.
if they've got a github account and Django work there, that's a good sign
@KrakensDen - thanks, makes me think that asking for any django related blog/twitter/githhub/bitbucket links might be the way to go.

Thanks for the responses. Occurs to me is that the main challenge is how to determine if someone has real experience, vs someone that is good at looking stuff up on Google.  Is seeing past work the best way to address that?
or a portfolio of past projects
a possible risk reduction strategy is fixed price for the first project, and if it was done quickly and well, per-hour after

@alexh why does it matter if someone is good at  looking up stuff on google and has little real experience? Obviously assuming he delivers quality work. Specially if you are talking about project that last a few hours at most days.

@adsworth - because I don't just want a hacked solution that just works.  I want a solution that has taken into account the alternative ways to achieve what's required, given the constraints and circumstances described.  That is what experience gives you and what Google doesn't.  I don't need to pay someone to look up Google, I can do that myself.  In other words, I'm interested in paying for someone's expertise, rather than just time.
I have 2 or 3 opensource reusable apps, if that's worth anything
i.e. Project/s != web site.   Project/s = architectural proof of concept or prototype.
@vasil - perhaps I'm missing it, but does Convore have a "contact me" button somewhere?
@alexh nope, you can see my twitter profile @ItarPeyo, DM me there, or you can suggest another method. I don't want to post my skype or email in public
mirrors
@alexh repos are here https://github.com/Atomidata/django-audit-log and this one https://github.com/Atomidata/django-private-files these are clones I tipicaly use mercurial

@alexh I don't have any Django stuff publicly available, but I work with it every day at my day job (I'm a web developer at Central Michigan University). I understand the framework pretty well, am comfortable digging into its source if necessary, and have written a custom LDAP authentication backend that I'd like to release in the future. Email is korol1bp at cmich.edu if you're interested, if not it's no big deal :)

@alexh you aren't going to find that kind of dev for the price you're describing. Anybody who has the experience you want is going to be at LEAST $50+ per hour, probably closer to $100. RentaCoder is almost certain to produce hackjobs - people who would do a decent job don't compete on price there. You're pricing your job for students and people who don't have experience.
agree with @PaulM. The sorts of devs you're describing are going to be much more than your budget. But they're worth it! Pay peanuts, get monkeys
@craigds  @PaulM I don't know of people who charge $100/hr or more in any profession where I live.
@paulm @craigds I feared that. Interesting that $100/hr exceeds what most experienced .NET/Java contractors get.
@alexh Not where I'm living.  The last .Net pros I hired I paid over $150 an hour for.  The last Java pros I was paying over $180 an hour (though, that WAS J2EE, which is especially painful.)

It's tough to say because the market is so different across the globe.  My experience is that $30 is not usually enough to get quality work across a large sample of developers.  $30/hr will go far in some countries though, and you can get good work for it, from near-native speakers, it's just a crapshoot, you've got to see code and know what you're looking for to be able to tell.
@alexh Ask for references and links to previous work, not infalible but indicative. Then start small and ditch the ones who can't hack it.
Thanks all for the advice
I got sick so I'm late to reply..

@alexh then we have a different understanding of what prototypes and proof-of-concept are. My understanding is that they are things that work to prove a concept or show what the end product can look like and not thoroughly thought out solutions.
@alexh - what's wrong with looking stuff up on google? Better than then someone who invents everything themselves and eats up your budget creating unmaintainable code.
@adsworth - not sure how arguing semantics helps me.
